body.l: LONDON, Printed by I. Raworth, for R. Whitaker.John Raworth was a printer in London between 1638 and 1645. He printed this play for Thomas Whitaker, a bookseller in London who, in partnership with Richard Whitaker, “had an extensive business, and published much of the best literature of the period,” according to A Dictionary of the Booksellers and Printers who Were at Work in England, Scotland and Ireland from 1641 to 1667. They also printed another of the plays produced by James Shirley during his time in Dublin: St. Patrick of Ireland. 1640.

div.head: The names of the Persons.
div.l: Hartwell, a young Gentleman, Lover of Mistresse Frances.
Four Servants, three disguised sometimes as Lords, one of them twice disguised as a Pursevant.

Bellamy, a WiddowAlthough Bellamy and Frances are two main characters in this play, they appear at the end of the list because it was common at the time to give the male roles first, followed by the female ones..

Neece to HornetShe is also one of the characters that in Act IV, Scene III performs a masque. The other characters in the masque are Paris, represented by Playfaire; and Juno, Pallas, Venus, Cupid, King and Soldier, who we do not know by whom they are played..

div.stage: Enter Hartwell, Close, and three other Servants.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay let’s not part so heavily.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: For mine owne part
It does not trouble me so much, that you
Have broke up house; for hospitalitie

Went out of fashion with crop-doublets
†crop-doublet. A short doublet. Obsolete.(OED n. C3).
doublet. A close-fitting body-garment, with or without sleeves, worn by men from the 14th to the 18th centuries. (Rarely applied to a similar garment worn by women.) Obsolete exc. Historical. (OED n. 1a).

And cod-peeces cod-peeces A (padded) pouch attached to the front of a man's close-fitting hose or breeches to cover the genitals, commonly worn in the 15th and 16th cent. (OED “codpiece”, n. 1a).: but I that have worne out
So many liveries under the worshipfull
Old Gentleman your father.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: My father had an office, which brought in
A faire revenew; I inherit but
His little land, whose annuall profits wo'not
Encourage me to live at the same height:
Yee may meet better fortunes, there's enough
Preferment in the world; my love and best
Assistance promise to your selves.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I do not
Stand upon wages, Sir, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: How woot thou live?

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: As other mortals do; yet I'll not play
The thiefe, that is a course by which a man
May soone ascend the ladder of preferment:
But I ne're lov'd these climbing trees. I cannot
Cheat, though I have heard there is an art,
A devillish deale of knowledge in the dice;
And if men wonot part with money, some
Will fetch it out o'th' bones: but the best casting
Is in a Taverne, when the wine and reckoning
Come up together; some doe spin a living by't:
And there are many secret wayes for Serving-men
To live, it is not wages does maintaine
All of our Tribe, Sir; and especially
Those that have Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: But I am a BachelourIn the 17th and 18th centuries, it was common in English-language texts to capitalise the first letter of common “important” nouns, probably as a result of the influence of continental, particularly German, books. However, this was not done systematically; one reason may be that each printer had their own personal preferences. .

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I pray let me be one of your buttons still then,
I am not halfe worne out; you know what mould
I'm made off, I did ever honest service;
And though my fellow Vermin can forsake
Your falling house, I doe not feare the rafters;
By this hand, Sir, I'll wait upon you, though
Like great mens servants, I do live on nothing
But looks, and the aire of commendations.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, attend me,
The rest I here discharge, there's somewhat more,
Not worth the name of bountie, I wish all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: And there be
No remedy, heaven blesse you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with these
My fellowes, sorrow has made but a dry proverb,
I must toth' Taverne, and condole a quart.

sp.speaker: Hartwell.
sp.l: Meet me at Mistresse Bellamy’s then.

div.fw: The Constant Maid, Act I Scene I

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: How now Masters.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: You speake not
To me, Sir, I am a servant still indeed;
With them the case is alter'd, they are masters,
For they want services.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: Oh, Master Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: It is not now as when Andrea liv'dAs the 1833 editor points out, some of the lines said by the servants in this passage are taken from Hieronimo’s monologue in scene V of The Spanish Tragedy, a very popular and influential play in the English Renaissance theatre written by Thomas Kyd between 1582 and 1592. ,

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: This place was made for pleasure, not for death.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: There was a time when mortals whetted knives.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: In time of yore, when men kill'd brutish beasts.

sp.speaker: Servant 3.
sp.l: Oh cruell Butcher, whosoe're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: Do not you know what all this signifies?

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: My master has given over house-keeping.

sp.speaker: Servant 1.
sp.l: He has committed Burglarie, broke up the cellar,
And throwne the kitchin out at the hall window.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: His house, Sir, has a superscription,
And is directed to his loving friend
Will pay the rent, you'l hardly know me now,
I have no fellow.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: You are verie merrie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Servant 2.
sp.l: He has some cause, we are discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: For certaine, my master only
Belongs to me, if you would speake with him,
He's gone to Mistresse Bellamy’s, Sir;
In the meane time, please you to understand,
I Close follow my master, and shall feed still,
Although my fellowes here are become blanks,
And do want filling.

sp.speaker: Playfaire.
sp.l: Lads, I have knowne you long:
Although you be at losse, in confidence
Of all your future honesties, I'll employ yee
In a device, which if it hit, may
Reward your paines.

sp.speaker: Close.
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Your Master only, Sir, belongs to you,
Follow him still, and if there be occasion,
I shall enquire for you; you will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Servants Omnes
sp.l: Doubt not, Mr. Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I have a project,
Follow me for instructions; farewell Close,
Commend me to your master.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: Buoy Close, buoy honest Close, we are blanks, blanks.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Roule up your selves in paper-liveries, and
Be drawne at the next Lotterie; I wo'not
Forsake my certaintie for all your projects,
If it should faile I shall find some of you

Sneaking in Paul'sClose is most probably referring to the Old St Paul’s Cathedral, which was destroyed shortly afterwards in the Great Fire of London in 1666 and rebuilt as we know it today. Despite its decay at the time, the cathedral was in the 17th century one of the focal points of London’s cultural, literary and political life, as well as a popular pilgrimage site. behind a pillar, with
A zealous prayer, some Gentleman would read

The bed-roll†bed-roll. A list of persons to be specially prayed for. Obsolete or archaic.(OED “bead-roll”, n. 1). of your commendationcommendation.An office originally ending with the prayer Tibi, Domine, commendamus, in which the souls of the dead were commended to God; said both before their burial, and in anniversary or commemorative services. Liturgical (gen. In plural; also Commendation of Souls). (OED n. II. 6a). Commendatory prayer (OED n. II. 6b).,
And pitie a verie serviceable fellow,
That would faine wait on him, but wants a cloake:
Go, prosper with your project.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy’s House.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Widdow, be rul'd by me, I know the world,
And I have studied it these fiftie yeares:
There's no man to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Without good.
Securitie, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No young man, widdow,
That talks, and sayes he loves you, writes you verses,
And sweares he shall goe hang himselfe, unlesse
You pitie him; take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: So, take you an old man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Season'd with care and thrift, not led away
By vicious conversation, nor corrupted
With pride and surfeit, one that knowes the use
Of money; Do yee mark the use?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, Sir:
Use upon use, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And dares not spend it prodigally, knowing
The principall end it was ordain'd to, was
To releeve our necessitie, and lay up
What is above.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: To help the poore.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You may,
If you be so dispos'd, but 'tis as commendable
To give it in your will, to build an Hospitall,
And so our charitie comes altogether:
I would not have your state be eaten up
By Catterpillers, but preserv'd and made
Greater, by marrying some discreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And such an one you show your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You happily
Interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I would not tell you, Sir,
Till our next meeting, how much you have won,
By your good counsell, on me.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She inclines.
'Tis your good nature, I am plaine, and have
No tricks, I'll tell you all my fault, I am
Addicted verie much to gather wealth;
I have no children to devoure my state,
Nor kinred, only a Neece left to my trust,
One that is never like to marrie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She never thriv'd since she came to mee.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I easily beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Melancholly
Will kill her, and yet I pursue all wayes
That promise her delight: I spare no cost
Of Physick, what her Doctor sayes, is done.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis lovingly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Gentleman that beares my daughter much
Affection.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Sure I have seene him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, he's a beggar, or must be verie shortly.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have you his lands in morgage?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Not yet, not yet; but he'll want money, widdow.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: He has had good breeding.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unlucky,
They never keep their state that have too much on't,
Counsell your daughter, Mistresse Bellamy,
To throw him off betime†betime.In good time, early, seasonably. Obsolete. (OED adv. 1)..

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You direct well.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: When we are married, I'll provide a match for her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You have care on's.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: It will become me.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is he Suitor to your mother, Lady?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: He would be such a thing: Were not I blest
In such a jolly father in law?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: He looks like some cast money-bag, that had given up
The stuffing, and for want of use growne mouldy:
He dares not keep much fire in's kitchin, lest
Warming his hands, which rather looke like gloves,
So tann'd and thin, he let em scorch, and gather
Into a heap. I do not think he ever
Put off his clothes, he would run-mad to see
His owne anatomy, that such a wretch
Should have so vast a wealth.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I wod not be his
Niece for all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I presume
Your mother is more noble, than to encourage him
In his pretence, and her estate would mix
But ill with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widdowes and from or plans, nor will all
His plentie keep his soule one day from famine:
'Tis time ill spent to mention him, let's talk
Of something else.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Of love agen,
Whose flame we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they shut up doores
First, that keep open house and entertainments:
This Lord is feasted, and that young Ladies
Sweet tooth must have a banquet; t'other old
Madam with ne're a tooth must have some marchpanemarchpane.Historical for “marzipan”.
Corall to rub her gums withall; these are
Ridiculous expences.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Far from thrift.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: This roome has too rich furniture, and worse
Hangings would serve the turne; if I may be
Worthy to counsell, costly pictures are
Superfluous, though of this, or t'other masters
Doing: Hang Michael AngeloMichelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (1475-1564), Italian Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect and poet. and his oyles.
If they be given, y'are the more excus'd
To let 'em shew; but have a care you let not
Appeare, either in Arras, or in picture,

The storie of the ProdigallHornet advises Bellamy not to display art depicting the Parable of the Prodigal Son, one of the parables of Jesus Christ in the Bible, appearing in Luke 15:11-32. The parable is framed as a response to a criticism of Jesus by the Pharisees and scribes for receiving sinners and eating with them, and emphasises God’s mercy towards the repentant. Hornet seems to warn that, if Bellamy shows this parable to her young male guests, they may restrict how much they spend on their dowries., 'twill fright
Young Gentlemen that come to visit you
From spending o'their portions, whose riot
May enrich you with their forfeited estates;
I have a thousand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But do not
Think all this while of heaven.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis in my chest,
And multiplyed in everie bag.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Or Hell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A fable to fright fooles, or children; but
I cannot stay, my Scrivener doth expect me,
I'll visit you another time, sweet widdow,
And give you more instructions.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Spare your travell
I sha'not practise these in haste, and must
Declare these precepts make not for your welcome:
My patience was a vertue all this while,
If you but think you have a soule; repent;
Your rules I am not covetous to follow,
Good master Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Live and be undone then:
You'l tell me another tale hereafter widdow.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Letters from Master Startup, the countrey Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A Sutor of my Nurses commendations.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Now heaven deliver me, what have I seen?
This monster once was shewne i'th' faire, or such
Another furr'd Baboone for all the world,
Do'st know him? Why do I ask such a question?
He's such a thing the Devill would not owne's
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Master Hornet, the great Usurer.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Hornet? Nay then, my wonder's over, and the
Devill be but such another, they
May be sworne brothers; yes, and divide hell
Betwixt em.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who is that you talk on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: The beast, that Heaven be thank'd, has left you,
Hornet; but I ha newes for you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I'll heare it in the garden.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Do you love
That Master Hartwell? do not blush, but answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I hope you move†move.Transitive. To propose or suggest (something to be done); to prefer (a request); to lodge (a complaint); to bring forward, propound (a question, etc.), mention (a matter). Also with to (a person). Obsolete. (OED v. 30a). not this, as if you doubted;
I took him first, upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But things alter:
What then I thought, I deliver'd yee;
Nor since hath he deserv'd a lesse esteeme
In his owne person, but the circumstance
Is not the same, his fortune I have examin'd,
Which rises not to such a value, I
Did apprehend; and it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my estate, to look for one whose purse
May carrie a proportion.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of shining dust, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nor
To penurie; his birth, and education
Are not unworthy, he's a handsome man too;
But be not govern'd by your eye too much:
Children and age pursue, and many stormes
Hover about our fraile conditions:
All these must be provided for, they are not
Kisses will arme you against winter, therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your best thoughts,

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Oh my unhappinesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Countrey Gentleman of spreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not spun the finest, but his wealth,
Able to guild deformitie, and make
Even want of wit a vertue, when your life
Renders it selfe more sweet by your command;
His name is Master Startup, whom I expect
Our guest to morrow, that's his letter, read it.
This may seeme strange at the first coming toward you;
But when discretion comes to examine what
A fruitfull consequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother,
Although I could dispence with my owne thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for my honour, or my fame? when such
A noble Gentleman shall boast he had,
With your consent, my love? or pray admit
That which we gaine by riches of the second,
Seeme to authorize, and may justifie
The act with some; how can it cure the wound,
Which the poore heart, which loves, shall find too soone,
When 'tis neglected, and so cruelly,
Where it did hope for cherishing? Oh think
How you did love my father first, and be
More gentle to your daughter, your estate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new stock; it doth grow already
Faire from his owne root, and doth want no peecing:
Nor are the meanes of Hartwell so contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: No more: y'have consider'd well, you'l shape
Another answer; i'th' meane time dispose
Your countenance to entertaine this new
And able Lover: leave the satisfaction
Of Hartwell to my care:
He's here, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themselves yet;
But he has a project to employ 'em all.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I wish it well; but do you work your selfe
Into the opinion of her Nurse, she is
The Major Domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her Sir like wax,
To print what forme you please upon her, 'tis
A Loving Crone already to me, I
Will speake her faire, and in my drink may marrie her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: About your businesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: There is a matter, Sir, which I must open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You prepare my attention.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
At least I think so.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident, in her I sum
All my desires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Be not so fixt.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: How Lady?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: When you have heard me out, you'l find
Your consent easie to call back a promise
Made to your disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I acknowledge;
This makes me wonder, pray interpret Lady,
And speake the dialect I understand:
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But must never glorie
In the reward which you expect should be,
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guiltie of so much
Offence to you, that I should be so soone
Lost to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have no thought so poore
You can deserve lesse, my opinion
Is richer laden with your merit.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Now I feare agen, this violent turne of praise
Makes me suspect my state; if I be falne,
Teach me to know my trespasse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I ne're look'd
With such cleere eyes into your worth, and 'twere
A sin to generall goodnesse, to delay
The free resigne of that your worth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my mistake
Of something went before, love made me feare;
You said I never should enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which your selfe so late enclined to.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And must agen repeat, you cannot call
Her Bride.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Can you forbid this happinesse,
And love me?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, so deerly, Hartwell, I
Present my selfe to thy affection.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You fright my understanding.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Does the name
Of widdow sound displeasing, I have learn'd
Already to obey; my yeares are not
So many, with the thought, to freeze your bloud,
I weare no print of time deep in my brow:
Have my haires the innocence of age,
To speake me twice a child? Gentlemen active,
And of great birth, have courted my affection
And if they flatter not, commend my person.
Adde unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter,
Depending on my love, whose portion must
Flow from my bountie, or be nothing; make
A sober apprehension of this tender,
And think I was not able to suppresse
My silent flame, increast still by your vertues:
This minute give all hopes up for my daughter,
I can admit no Rivall; 'tis within
Your election to be happie, Sir:
My love accepted comes with faire attendance,
Deny'd, you hasten your owne exile, think on't,
I will expect your answer.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I am destroy'd:
Was it her mother that spake all this while?
As pilgrims, by mistake of some small path,
Having told many wearie steps, at night,
When their hopes flatter em, they are not far
From some kind entertainment, find themselves
Lost in a wildernesse; so am I miserable:
Thus love delights to wound, and see us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed.

div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy's House.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: A word of thy mouth does it, I am wearie

Of these indenturesindenturesA deed between two or more parties with mutual covenants, executed in two or more copies, all having their tops or edges correspondingly indentured or serrated for identification and security. Hence, A deed or sealed agreement or contract between two or more parties, without special reference to its form (OED n. "indenture" 2a)., like a foole, I was
In hope he should have married Mistresse Frances.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: A beggar, she his wife; no, Master Startup,
Whom I preferr'd, must carrie her, he's a man
Of lands and money; I must tell you by
The way, he is little better than a foole.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: The fitter for her husband, and my master.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Y'are in the right, he's innocent to your hands,
You may soone come to manage his estate.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Which if I do, thou shalt have all.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: All what?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Why all that I can beg, borrow, or steale
From him; what should he do with so much riches?
I'll prompt my mistresse, after the first yeare,
To put him to his pension; he should pay
For's verie diet, and after a moneth or two,
For everie time he comes aloft.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay, I would wish her to begin betimes,
If she doe meane to rule the roostto rule the roostTo have full sway or authority; to be master (OED “to rule the roast” P2a). , I can
Give her some documents; and be you sure
To stick close to your Mistresse, there is something
To be got that way.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: My most exquisite VargesAs the editor of the 1833 edition states, Close is probably alluding to Verges, a character in Shakespeare’s comedy Much Ado About Nothing. Verges is old and practical, a sidekick character who always appears alongside Dogberry. Together they function as a comic duo, much like Close and the Nurse in this play.,
How I doe love thy documents; but he's here,
I'll not be seene with thee, farewell, we'll talk

The rest at night over a Sack-posset†sackA general name for a class of white wines formerly imported from Spain and the Canaries (OED n. 3a).possetA drink made from hot milk curdled with ale, wine, or other liquor, flavoured with sugar, herbs, spices, etc., and often drunk for medicinal purposes (now historical); a kind of syllabub made from similar ingredients (OED n. 1)..

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I will use this advantage to overheare 'em.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You tell me strange things; Is it possible
The widdow her selfe loves you?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Would I had
But reason to suspect.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Possible!
Turn'd Cold againe? This love will kill us all:
And can she make no choyce, but where her daughter
Has the same longing? not her dancing dayes

Done yet?not her dancing dayes done.Morris Palmer Tilly records the proverb “My dancing days are done” in A dictionary of the proverbs in England in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries. This expression was used by playwrights of this period to refer to youth. Capulet says a similar expression in Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet: “for you and I are past our dancing days”. why there's no remedy, you must love her.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: And violate my faith made to her daughter.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Thou wilt not be so much an Infidell†InfidellOne who does not believe in (what the speaker holds to be) the true religion; an ‘unbeliever’. Obsolete. (OED n. “infidel” A1). In general sense: One who does not believe in something specified; an unbeliever (OED n. “Infidel” A4).,
To think I meane thou shouldst forsake the wench;
Tell me the mother a fine tale of love,
Print kisses on her paper-lip, and hug
Her reverend body; any thing but lie with her:
Write sonnets on the ivorie tooth afore,
Sweare she does cough distinctly, get a rime
To blesse her when she sneezes, and cry up
The method of her nose, which sweats and fals
So perpendicular upon her face:
Admire the wart upon her chin, and motion
Of her blue eyes, that look three wayes at once:
Praise her above thy reason, or her daughter;
And then she will beleeve thou mayst be mad for her.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is this the way to doe me good? she comes
Too fast on me already.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Let her flie to thee,
Thou mayst clip her wings the sooner, this secures thee;
Shou'd you hold off, and play the modest creature;
Nay, but deny as Maids do when they love it,
And bending of your hams, cry, No forsooth;
Professe with Coxcomb†CoxcombA stupid person, a fool. Obsolete. (OED n. 4a). A vain, conceited, or pretentious man (OED n. 4b)-like civilitie,
You are not worthy of her carnall favors:
She may beleeve it, and in verie spight
Marrie her daughter to a Citizen:
Or should you be so mad, to think to win her
To your first choyse, with howling out your passion
For Mistresse Frances, plaining how Don CupidCupid. In Roman Mythology, the god of love, son of Mercury and Venus, identified with the Greek Eros (OED n. 1a).
Hath scarrified your heart, you may go hang your selfe:
Go to the Barber’s, let him firk your haire upfirk your haire up.Probably to stir up, rouse (OED “to firk up (figurative)”, v. 2b).,

Or get a perriwigperriwigAny highly stylized wig of a kind formerly worn by men and women, and (esp. in Britain and parts of the British Commonwealth) retained by judges and barristers as part of their professional dress. More generally: a wig of any kind (OED n. “periwig” 1a). archaic; wash your sullen face,
And starchstarchTo stiffen (cloth, clothes, etc.) with starch (OED v. 1a) your infant upper lip, to look
Like one that would run desperate on a widdow.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Precious conspiracie.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: This is the way:
At leisure you may tell your Maiden Mistresse,

Like JoveJoveA poetical equivalent of Jupiter, name of the highest deity of the ancient Romans (OED, n. 1a).Jupiter is the supreme deity of the ancient Romans, corresponding to the Greek Zeus; the ruler of gods and men, and the god of the heavens, whose weapon was the thunderbolt (OED, n. 1a). you have put another shape on,
To cheat the Beldam Juno.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Foule mouth'dfoule mouth.A person who speaks in an offensive or disgraceful way, (now) spec. one who uses coarse or obscene language; a foul-mouthed person (OED “foulmouth” n. A). Rascall.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I apprehend: th'ast given me good counsell,
I'll watch the first occasion, to assure
I have preferr'd her in my heart already.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I'll conjure up a crosse plot, and that quickly,
Shall mar your mirth, and pay your fine dissembling

As it deserves, my confident Love-gamester The Gamester is the title of one of James Shirley’s plays, a comedy of manners premiered in 1633 and published in 1637. After hearing Playfair and Hartwell’s plot, the Nurse refers to the latter as a gamester (gambler), someone who plays love games..

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I'll take my leave then, y'have no other service
To use my stay? I have a project,Hartwell,
That must not be neglected.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: May not I communicate?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Thou art engaged to wait
Upon thine owne affaires, or I should trouble thee
To be an Actor in't; thou knowest old Hornet?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: He is a Sutour to the widdow,
And after the rate we cast the plot, my Rivall.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I'll rivall him; he smothers a poore Gentlewoman
At home with sea-cole, and allowes her no
More light than serves to read in painted cloth

The exposition of the harlot’s storie This could be an allusion to a biblical story, since in Act I, Scene II, Hornet advises Bellamy to hang a picture depicting another biblical story, that of the Prodigal Son. Although there are many references to harlots in the Bible, in this case they could be talking about Rahab, “the harlot of Jericho”. Rahab helped the Israelites capture Jericho, and she and her family were then incorporated as Jewish people. Hornet, a Jew, would see in her a good example of his faith. Indeed, as Hornet explains to Bellamy in Act I, he believes that paintings should be displayed to convey certain messages. In this case, Rahab would be an example of faith, virtuosity and righteous behaviour to his niece (to whom, on more than one occasion, he refers in similar terms to “harlot”). However, given that this play is full of classical references, they could also be talking about Helen of Troy, usually portrayed as the one responsible for the Trojan War by abandoning Menelaus for Paris. This interpretation would also make sense, since in the masque in Act IV, Scene III, Playfaire will play Paris and the Neece will play Helen.:
Hartwell, I love her, and before her father
Died we enterchang'd our hearts; 'tis here,
To free her from that slaverie she lives in
Under the iron-hearted Jaylor, else
I shall repent my aime, he broods upon†broods upon.To produce by brooding upon; to breed. (Cf. Gen. i. 2.) Obsolete. (OED “brood”, v. 1b).
Her portion still; but I have a trick may spoile
His hatching of young bags, thou shalt know all
Hereafter; to the Widdow, Hartwell, I am
For state affaires, be faithfull and pray for me;
We must be bold, farewell, if something hit

Wee'll laugh in spight of DivesDivesDivesThe Latin word for ‘rich (man)’, occurring in the Vulgate, Luke xvi; whence commonly taken as the proper name of the rich man in that parable; and used generically for ‘rich man’ (OED n. 1). and the Devill.

div.stage: Enter Startup, Mistresse Bellamy, Mistresse Frances, Close, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: This is the thing, Sir, that must carrie away
The garland, they have given him a cup
Or two of Sack, and has the prettiest humour,
He does so whistle out his complement:
He weares his feather like the Captaine of
A Countrey Teame, and would become a horse-collar
Rarely; I do not think, but were he put to 't,
With little switching, he would draw the cart well.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Lady, I'm your humble servant, 'tis
Well knowne what I am, where I live, my father
Died since I was of age; and left me, thank him,
A younger brother’s portion:

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A younger brother.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I know, sweet Lady, what you'd say, My father
Had no more children; but I must speake modestly
Of my estate, I have land I know enough
For two or three wives; I have a horse in towne,
Your daughter, if we please, shall ride behind me,
Sweet Lady, did you ever see the Countrey?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: What Countrey, Sir?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why any Countrey living,
Sweet Lady, I am your humble servant, if
You affect hawking, hunting, or drinking,
There be good fellowes will beare you company; but you have
better Sack, sweet Lady, is there good Tobacco in London?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Virginia Tobacco growes here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, I am your humble servant, you
Seeme to be a Gentleman, will you fetch me a pipe?
There's halfe a peece, and I be not troublesome:
Perhaps, sweet Lady, 'twill offend you, then
Let it alone.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: A verie precious WidginWidginWild duck species (OED n. “wigeon” 1b).: Gramercie†GramercieThanks; thank you (OED int. 1a). Used as an exclamation of surprise or sudden feeling; = ‘mercy on us!’ Obsolete. (OED int. “gramercy” 2). Sack.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Ta la la la lero, &c.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: You dance well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: He has a strong back, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Lady, is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Ask that now?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I was her mother, Sir.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: That may be too: what Gentleman is that?
Sweet Sir, I am your humble servant likewise.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You are too humble, Sir, to stoop so low,
It would become my dutie.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, 'tis all one,
A leg or an arme is not cast away
Among friends, I am a Countrey Gentleman
All the world knowes, sweet Sir, I ha no businesse
In towne.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I thought you came to see my daughter.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: That may be too, sweet Lady, pray uncase me,
I honour your faire daughter; for I know,
As well as another, what belongs to a Gentlewoman:
She's not the first, sweet Lady, I have lov'd
I'th' way of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Were you ever married?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, not all men are not alike.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: For some are fooles.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, I do confesse it:
But wit is never good till it be bought.
They say there are good wits in towne,
I ha brought money a purpose with mee for it;
If any will sell me a penny-worth, I'll
Give him a hundred peeces, 'cause I would carrie
A little downe into the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is there
A dearth, Sir, in your Countrey?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, no;
There's plentie.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Of wild oats; I heard you had much
To sow still.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: My servants have, sweet Sir; but 'tis all one;
This Lady shall be Lord o' the Soyle: I wo'not
Give any man six pence for a bushell o' money;
I am a Gentleman, my father was
A Yeoman; but sweet Lady, howsoever
I'm yours, and everie limb is at your service;
My hands shall walk, my feet shall run.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: By this gold they shall.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: He keeps his oath.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Not run? my Grandfather was a Nobleman Foot-man,
and indeed he run his countrey; my father did outrun the Con-
stable.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And he, sweet Lady, being his father’s issue, must run na-
turally.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: If I live.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: He'll run himselfe out of all.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Not run, sweet Lady?
If you have occasion to use me, I wo'not stand upon my feet.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Nay, I wo'not stand upon my head, sweet Lady, to doe
you courtesie.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: That were the cleane contrarie way.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Please you, a sorrie dinner stayes for you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Lady, I am your servant: will this Gentleman
dine with us?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I'll prevaile with Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Do yee know what you ha done? he's you rivall,
invite him?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, I invite no body, if you love any body here?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, I shannot take it kindly, I do not use to quarrel.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: But when y'are beaten: lay him o're the face, hee sha'not
wrong you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Sir, 'tis dinner time: faire Lady:

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I had a great mind to have him beaten;
But he's not valiant, but at meales; would I
Were hired to beat him handsomely after dinner,
And make him thank me for't; I'll have a plot
Upon your precious body, my sweet Sir.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Hornet, Playfaire’s Cousen disguised like a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You tell me wonders, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I tell you truth:
Alas, you know I have no ends of profit,
I practise not for wealth.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Y'are vertuous;
For that you were commended, Sir, to me:
You have a conscience, and wo'not take
Fees for a complement, nor make poore your friends,

To enrich Apothecaries ApothecariesOne who kept a store or shop of non-perishable commodities, spices, drugs, comfits, preserves, etc. (OED n. “apothecary” 1). In the context of The Constant Maid, it could mean to better one’s self financially or otherwise..

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I have cur'd her melancholly; but she's a t'other side
Now extreme merrie, dance and sing, all aire.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis strange, methinks, nothing but extremities:
Good Master Doctor, could you not ha par'd
Her t'other leaden humor.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sir, I could not
Kill the malignitie of her melancholly
Another way; extremities must be cur'd
With extreme applications: my next work
Shall be to abate this levitie of her braine,
And quallifie her spleene, Sir, by degrees;
So state her body in that modest temper
She was possest of.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I complain'd before
Of quietnesse, now she's all noyse and madnesse,
By your description.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: You must have patience
A month or so, she is not mad, but merrie,
Some few vagaries; you must understand
I have opend, Sir, her fancie, wherein lay
All her imaginations confused,
And on a heap, smother'd for want of vent;
And now the spirits that were imprison'd
Rush out, which causes all her faculties,
Before opprest, to exercise so strangely,
As the agitation of her tongue will manifest:
Shee's here.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Uncle, how does your body? you appeare

As leaneleaneWanting in flesh; not plump or fat; thin (OED adj. 1a). as Lentlent
Chiefly with capital initial. A period of fasting and penitence, beginning on Ash Wednesday and ending shortly before Easter, observed in the Christian Church in commemoration of the time Jesus spent in the wilderness. Now also: a period of fasting or abstinence observed at the same time in secular culture. Formerly also in: † Clean Lent in the same sense (obsolete). (OED n. 2a).
As other characters through the play, the Neece is commenting on Hornet’s thinness., I've a great mind to dance
About a May-pole, shall we?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She is mad.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: This Doctor has for tickled me,
cannot chuse but laugh, ha, ha.
Unckle, if you'l procure a dispensation
To marrie me your selfe, deduct the charge
Out of my portion, I could love an old man

Rarely, An old man with a bed full of bones & c.The Neece could be singing “The Old Man with a Bed Full of Bones”, an English Country Dance first recorded in the Lovelace Manuscript, a document that contains poems, songs and dances written between 1621 and 1649.
Unckle, when did you put on a clean shirt?
D'yee heare, I dreamt o'th' Devill last night,
They say 'tis good luck; doe you know him, Unckle?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I know the Devill?

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: He's a fine old Gentleman,
And something like you, no such Bug-beare as
The world imagines, you an he'll keep house
Together one day; but you'll burne Sea-cole
To save charges, and stink the poore soules so.
Unckle, you are not merrie, I pray laugh
A little: imagine y'had undone a widdow,
Or turn'd an Orphan begging; ha, ha, ha.
Faith how many Churches doe you meane to build
Before you die? six bels in everie steeple,
And let'em all goe to the Citie tune,

Turne agen Whittington;The Neece refers to a ballad about Richard Whittington (c. 1354–1423), a wealthy merchant and later Lord Mayor of London. The legend says he made a fortune through the sale of his cat to a rat-infested country. The Niece makes reference to this same story in the following lines. Also known as “An Old Ballad of Whittington and his cat” or “Londons Glory, and Whittingtons Renown”, the ballad was very popular during the 17th and 18th centuries. The earliest surviving piece that makes reference to this story dates from 1612. who, they say,
Grew rich, and let his land out for nine lives,
'Cause all came in by a Cat: but let me counsell you
To die at all adventures, great men doe't in policie.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Why does she talk of dying? she's stark mad.
Could you not put into the next receit
Something to make her sleep well? Opium
In a good quantitie, they say, will do't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll so proportion it, she shall never wake:
I did it for a Merchant’s wife last weeke,
Which loved a Knight: a great man, not long since
Was wearie of his Countesse, and I cur'd him
So artificially of his disease.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She heares.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: But collects nothing; all her senses are scatter'd.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Stay, you shall give towards the building of a Church
Nothing, see the money first laid out,
That's given already; it were sin and pitie
To abuse the dead: but 'tis no matter, Unckle,
You'll be as famous for pulling downe the parish,

The Church will fall of it selfe, >With ding dong bell."Ding Dong Bell" is a nursery rhyme, a traditional song for children, first recorded in 1580 by John Lant, the organist of Winchester Cathedral. The phrase “Ding Dong Bell” appears in two Shakespeare’s plays: The Tempest and The Merchant of Venice.
Why did they put the poore fellow in prison?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Whom? what fellow?

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Why the Corne-cutter:
Poore Gentleman, he meant no hurt to the Citie,
His feet were verie wearie, and that made him

In everie street cry out; >Ha yee any cornesGiven the context of the scene and the previous references, "Ha yee any cornes in your head or toes" is probably an allusion to another old English song. However, the title is unknown.
In your head or toes? that head spoyl'd all.

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: Which is Master Hornet?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Ha, with me?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: A word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Prethee, what's he? he comes to borrow money
On his wives wedding-ring, or his child's whistle:
You may see by his nose he has no land, he looks
As a Hawke; what do you dreame on?
What Ladies timpany is your next cure?
Or whose stale body must be rectified

Next with a glister glisterA glistering; a bright light, brilliance, lustre (OED, n. 1). In the 1833 edition “glister” is replaced by “clyster”. The Neece says “Next with a clyster?” Clyster refers to a medicine injected into the rectum, to empty or cleanse the bowels, to afford nutrition, etc.; an injection, enema; sometimes, a suppository (OED n, 1a). The reason for this change is unclear.?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: There is no disputing, I must attend you.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am sent for by a Pursevant to his Highnesse;
Alas, I am undone, I never saw him,
How should he know me, a poore wretch?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Is't not some complaint, think you?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: That's my feare, there be
Too many knaves i'th' world, and a man cannot
Grow rich; but one State-Surgeon or other
Must practise on his purse; before this Judge
A veine is open'd in the other Court,
So many ounces he must bleed agen:
Let me see, all the treason I committed
Is that I shifted houses; for I took
Delight to couzen him of his subsidies;
I alwayes live obscurely, to avoyd
Taxations, I never pay the Church

Her superstitious tithestithes. A tenth of annual produce or earnings, taken as a tax (originally in kind) for the support of the church and clergy; this system of taxation; now chiefly historical. Later also, in certain religious denominations: one tenth of an individual's income, pledged to the church (OED n.2. 1a)., nor come to trouble
Sermons, for feare of homilies before,
That beg for burning.

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Why how now, Unckle, is your Scrivener broke,
You talk such lamentation?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am sent for the King, Neece, & shall be made a beggar
As I was borne; I see my chattell ceas'd,
This chest is ransackt, and that bag deflour'd,
My doore seal'd up, and with this hungrie Messenger,
I am already marching to the FleetMost certainly a reference to Fleet Prison, a prison by the side of the River Fleet in London. It was mainly used for debtors and bankrupts..

sp.speaker: Neece
sp.l: Nay, and you be at that ward, I must leave you,
Fare well, pray do not lift my Uncle too hard;
And so I leave you both to the mercy of the Bear-garden.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Best make fast her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I, I, cursed dog.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Wo' not some money quallifie your haste?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: Deale in your owne affairs; Will you go sit?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Go, I must go.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I'll take my leave;
Have comfort, sir, this cloud may soon blow over.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Yes, when I am blowne up;
I reade imprisonment in his very looks,
And all my gold confiscate.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy's House.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I heard her say she would walke up to her chamber,
The trick was but to teach him whither he
Should follow; who as nimbly apprehended,
To acquaint her with his new affections:
I do this for your good, that Mistresse Frances,
Whom I'll send to you presently, may be
Convinced in Hartwell's falshood, and transplant
Her love on you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: This will be excellent;
So we shall strangle him in his owne nooze,
And he never know who hurt him.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I'll loose no time, you know my instructions.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I had almost forgot, there is a cast of angelsangels.A gold coin issued in England between 1465 and c1642, bearing the figure of the archangel Michael killing a dragon. Now chiefly historical or archaic. (OED n. III 10). more.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: They are not cast away.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: If thou dost fear they'll drowne, Nurse, I can give thee
Lighter, I have some want weight.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: If you have an evill angelIn France and England there was a superstitious belief that the royal touch could cure scrofula, also known as “the king's evil”. The kings of England performed ceremonies in which they laid hands on sufferers, and then presented them a gold Angel coin. about you,
Your businesse will thrive better when 'tis departed.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Now all the good ones wait upon your worship.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: These things that go to and agen, must have
Their fees, they'll never speak in cause else.
Save you sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Kinde Mr. Startup.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Yes, I am kinde if you knew all, but you are
Deceiv'd in some body; love, and love your heart out,
The party does not care a button for you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: What party?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: No, I am a foole, a countrey clod, sweet Lady,
Not worth one of your Shooe-tyes, no not I;
I do not know who makes an asse of you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: A gull, a coxcomb, I am asham'd you have
So little wit; Tell me, and tell me truly,
Who loves this face of yours besides my selfe.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Although it were immodest to commend it,
I must thus far, in gratitude to nature,
Acknowledge it no monster, I have seen
One more deform'd.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Sweet Lady I know that;
A worse face would become the Countrey, nay,
There are but fifteen women in the parish
I live in, of which, twelve are counted witches,
And wear beards: But it troubles me, sweet Lady,
You should be such an owle.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: This is course language.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Not to see who abuses you; Oh I could

Now finde in my heart to bastebaste.
Probably to beat or thrash (a person, animal, etc.), esp. with a stick or other implement; to flog”. Originally Scottish. In later use regional, slang, and colloquial. transitive. (OED v. 3.).
A few lines later, Startup makes another reference to beating, when he says “I could kick your ignorance”. you, baste you soundly:
You think Mr. Hartwell loves you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I
Believe he hates me not.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Good words.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: You lie most basely, he affects your mother.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My mother? this fool's mad.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I would it were
The fashion for women to weare swords.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I'de breath you into a little understanding,
I say agen, and she is the son of darknesse
Denyes it; Mr. Hartwell loves your mother.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I hope he does.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Oh I could kick your ignorance:
He does love her in the way of Matrimony,
And makes a property of you; I'll justifie it.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: D'ee know that couple?
sp.stage: Enter behind Hartwell and mistresse Bellamy.
sp.l: Step behinde the hangings, and you may
Both hear and see: I say no more, sweet Lady,
I am a rustick puppy, and know nothing.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I have considered perfectly, and if
You will vouchsafe me hearing, dare poure forth
My heart, which, full of love, tenders it selfe
To your acceptance; I acknowledge, Lady,
My passions are but young, for could I hope
You should with so much favour look upon me?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But may I credit this?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: But suspect were an injustice to my faith, which lookes
Upon your vertue with as much religion
As love is able to receive; your age
Hath strooke a reverence into my eye;
And what you want of youth and spring upon you,
Your wisedome richly satisfies: Those characters
Which time hath writ upon your carefull forehead,
Are but his vertue and your ornament,
When it shall come to passe by your example,
That youth shall be esteemed an infancy,
And women never ripe for love or Marriage
Without your age upon 'em; 'tis a fault,
That men not guided by the tract of reason,
But heat and wantonnesse of blood, run giddy
To seale such weighty Covenants, better 'twere
The world should end in our virginities,
Than spin it selfe more length by inconsiderate
And hasty marriages.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have you already
Retriv'd the affection that pursu'd my daughter?
Shall I beleeve no seed of love remains,
Which may grow up and ripen, with repentance
For this exchange; I do allow you, sir,
The consideration of my fortune, which
Might of it selfe, incline you to accept me.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: That is but an attendant, as you use it,
I must confesse a welcome one; although
The minde is the first beauty, which true love
Aspires to, when 'tis waited on with person
And estate, it comes with greater priviledge
To win upon's; I do not wish you, Lady,
Rashly beleeve what I professe, but measure
My service by the triall; I'll expect
And write your smiles a competent reward,
Till time and your command, demonstrate me;
Although not equall to your full deservings,
Yet one that has ambition to be thought
Not too unworthy.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And I ghesse ere long,
Such an occasion will present it selfe.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Till then, have Hartwell in your loving memory,
Who wishes no more happinesse of life,
Than to be call'd yours.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: What have I understood?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Will you beleeve me another time, sweet Lady?
If I loved you not, what would become on you?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: It is not he, some devill does but couzen us,
And mock our sense with these phantastick bodies,
Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Nay 'tis the man; I hope you'll be converted,
And think a Countrey Gentleman worth favour,
That brought you to this knowledge; I deserve—

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My curses for this black discovery,
When as before 'twas not impossible,
In time I might be brought to pity thee;
Henceforth I'll look upon thee as my sins,
And beg as much forgivenesse that I knew thee.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Nay d'yee but hear.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Die quickly, and be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: This is very fine i’faith, sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My mother, oh my fate, see me no more,
And I’ll forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Thanke you, most sweet Lady,
Is my discovery come to this? I'de better
Ha'been tongue-ty'd; Curse me, and call me her sins,
And see her no more? why this is worse and worse;
I must suck better counsell from the Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Fye, fie, I am asham'd of you, a Gentleman
Of your high promising, and be put off
So slightly?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why Nurse, what would you ha' me do?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Do? I would have you do something; a man
Of your ability, and cannot turne
And winde a woman?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: You wo'd not ha' wish'd me
To ha' put her to't behinde the hangings?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You should ha' been round†roundOf a task: carried out to a proper finish; thoroughly accomplished or discharged. Obsolete. (OED adj. 13b). with her.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I was round with her, I call'd her asse and coxcombe,
And twenty more names, unlesse I should
Ha' call'd her whore, I could not be more round with her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I do not mean that way.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: And she call'd me,
I thank her.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Why no worse than her sins, heaven forgive her,
She has the more to answer; nay she did
Not stick to bid me die too, in that desparate
Estate.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come, you shall take another course.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What ayles my Masters sweet-heart, she frighted?
I met and askt her for my Master, and
She turn'd tayle lik a hound had lost the scent;
There's something in the winde, my three pil'd worship
Are you there with my Lady o'th' Larderlarder A room or closet in which meat and other provisions are stored (OED n. 1a).,
Now in that posture? do not they two look like
A fine Brick house and a thatched Barne in the Countrey,
Laying their heads together? they ha' spied me.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come hither Close, nay he's faithfull, and one that
Has a desire to serve you; you may trust him.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Your worship may trust me a bed with— I
Have had a itch this great while, sir, a kinde

Of longing to be one of your appurtenancesappurtenanceA thing that belongs to another, a ‘belonging’; a minor property, right, or privilege, belonging to another more important, and passing in possession with it; an appendage (OED n. 1).:
I have some faults, and I'll confesse 'em; I have
A humourhumourA particular disposition, inclination, or liking, esp. one having no apparent ground or reason; a fancy, a whim. Now archaic and rare (OED n. 6a). now and then, when I am ask'd
A question, to tell true, though I be chid for't;
And I do not love blowes; you may sooner beat
My braines out, than a word of flattery:
I cannot battenbattenTo feed gluttonously on, glut oneself; to gloat or revel in (OED v. 1b). upon commendation,
Without my wages, nor be valiant
Upon small Beere; I am not overmuch

Given to be drunke, but I've a tricke o'th DutchmanAllusions perpetuating the idea that the Dutch were heavy drinkers were common in 17th-century England. The English and the Dutch had a strong military and commercial rivalry, and thus would use this as a means of insulting one another.,
To do your businesse as well drunke as sober:
I have not impudence enough to pimpe
For you, but I have a gift I can say nothing:
I was borne upon ShrovetuesdayIn the 1833 version of The Constant Maid, it is noted that “Close alludes to the turbulent conduct of the city apprentices on this holiday.”, and shall be
Now and then given to rebellion:
My flesh will once a year rise at a Chamber-maid;
If none such take me downe, I shall in malice
And deep revenge, fling out upon May-day,

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: I like this humour.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Nay he has a sconcesconceA jocular term for: The head; esp. the crown or top of the head; hence, ‘head’, ability, sense, wit (OED n. 2).,
And shall be of our counsell: Look you Close,
There is a plot to helpe this Gentleman,
At night when they're a bed, and if you went
To bed betimes, to avoid suspicion,
'Twere never the worse; I'll say you are not well:
D'ee marke? this honest, honest Gentleman shall be
Let into Mistresse Frances Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Without her knowledge?

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: You shall only attend,
To give him notice from me when to come,
And watch about the house, he may get off
Without discovery; this is all.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: So, so, I sha' not keep the doore.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: I can do that.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Let me alone to give you notice who
Stirs about house.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, 'tis Mr. Hartwell;
We'll not be seen together.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Go your wayes,
A foolish Knave and Bawd, that do want nothing
But carting; I would sooner see that triumph,

Than all the PageansNote that the editor of the 1833 version of the constant maid changed this word to “pageants,” when it is meant to be “pagans.” The word “pagan” is being used in a derogatory manner here (OED “pagans” n. 1a)., a day after Symon

And JudeSimon and Jude were two of Jesus’ apostles who went together as missionaries to Persia, and were martyred there. Close’s comparison implies that the Nurse and Startup’s scheme against Frances is a tragedy of similar magnitude to these apostles being killed., when the fine City goes a feasting.
Oh Sir, I have newes; yes, they are gone, brave newes;
Your Gentlewoman can hold out no longer;
This night there will be a stratagem:
Old Madam Humpe a pompe, the Nurse, has promis'd
To admit the Countrey Gentleman, when all
Are a bed, into her chamber; yes, your Mistresse:

I'm o'th' plot, to lie Perdueto lie PerdueTo be placed as an outpost, guard, scout, etc., in an exposed or hazardous position. Also: to be hidden and on watch, to be lying in ambush. Obsolete. (OED “†perdu” adj. 2a)., and give
The word, if any Fire-lock approach

The restThe editor of the 1833 edition notes the meaning of this phrase: “If there be any imminent danger of a discovery; alluding to the preparatory step for immediate firing, which was, by bringing the musket to the rest, or forked support.”; imagine if he have not art to
Perswade her to the feat with him, yet there
Be tricks, and he may be surprized in the Chamber,
And she may be compell'd to marry him in
Her owne defence; there have been such devises.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Does he consent?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: She is betraid to't, sir.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Then thou wo't be so base?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And I had meant it,
I never had told you this: can you make use
Of this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Thou art my honest servant.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I promis'd to be his.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I have it; Canst
By any meanes procure me but his clothes?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: With ease, he'll go to bed betimes, to avoid
Suspicion; that's a part of our designe.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I could not wish a happy opportunity,
To try how she affects this gaudy foole,
And clear my faith to her, which her mothers watch
Will not permit; she has, I feare, perceiv'd
My new familiarity with her mother,
Which I am compell'd too, and must cleer this way:
Faile me not, Close, and propound thy owne
Reward.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Tell me your purpose, and let my wit
Dispose of him.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Prosper me love in this.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: And you fall to prayers
With good love, look about us, I shall suspect
You wo'not thrive; you should go to a wench,
As Gentlemen to Oysters, without ceremony
Or saying grace; devotion will spoile all.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Justice Clement's House. A banquet set out.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Right as an Arrow Couze.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Witty enginereenginereA person who makes engines, structures, or systems; or a constructor of military engines; a person who designs and constructs military works for attack and defence. Also figurative. Now chiefly historical (OED “enginer” n. I 1a).;
But was she taken with the plot?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: I was compell'd to frame the outside of a reason,
Lest our owne mirth should play the Traytor with us,

Her spleeneIn 17th-century medicine, the spleen was believed, along with the liver and gallbladder, to house three of the purported humours of the body: blood, yellow bile, and black bile. The spleen, specifically, was meant to hold black bile, which was believed to cause sadness and melancholy. The Cousin is likening the Neece’s false display of madness to someone with imbalanced humours. was so dilated, he beleeved
I have made her mad, which change makes for us.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: And he that we employed, the Pursevant,
Shewed such a fierie Raskall, the poore Usurer
Trembled, as Bawds beneath the lash.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: He comes then?

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: With as much joy, as to receive a hanging:
He would be whipt, and say his prayers i'th' Church
In a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: That were no pennance to him.

sp.speaker: Cousen
sp.l: Nay, he would pay as much as he should fine
For Alderman, though halfe his soule went with it,
For his quietnesse; he doth apprehend
Nothing but earth-quakes.

div.stage: Enter three servants, disguised as Lords.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: How am I rampant
With the imagination? bid the musick
Be ready, they know all their flourishes;
But shift you quickly for your other part,
My honourable Lords;

How they doe look like States-man, where's your tooth-pickIn the 17th century, toothpicks could be used as a way of showing off your status, as they would often be made extravagantly with metal and laid with gemstones. This is another small detail being used to keep up the ruse with Hornet, and convince him he is actually being knighted.?
Excellent; beare your staffe handsomely, contract
The brow, and look more superciliouslysuperciliouslyIn a supercilious manner; with an air of contemptuous indifference or superiority (OED adv. 1)..

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: I warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: We came now
From practise.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Can ye do't with confidence?

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: These verie clothes have made me proud already,
It was some Lords cast sute, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And mine, it smels of honour.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so, how now man?

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He looks pale: My Lord, how d'ee?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well, well, I hope 'tis but conceit.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Will the pox lie in clothes? I can not tell,
I finde some alteration in my body,
Since I shifted.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: 'Tis a meere conceit,
They were an honest mans, upon my knowledge,
A Captaine of the traine Band in the Countrey,
They were brought against the generall Master last;
He wore 'em that day, and to Church the Sunday
Following, and most carefully sent 'em up,
To taste our London Lavender.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Sir, you have satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Be sprightly; where's this Prince?
See and attend him in fit state.

div.stage: Re-enter Cousen disguised as the King, and three servants as Lords, Sir Clement.
Cousen sits himself at the head of the board.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: He's here.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Now by that sprig, a pretty Majesty;
But wo't thou not be out of thy Kings part?
And when the Wine is wanting at the Banquet,
Call upon drawers, quarrell with your Nobles,
Or when we shall present our man of morgages,
Take him aside, and borrow halfe a crowne,
To give your whore benevolence, which trusted,
For you last tilting, or be drunke too soone,
And leave our project in the dirt.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My Lords,
This fellowes insolence must be corrected;
Dispose him in what prison you think fit.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He's mad, I thinke.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: To Bedlambedlam An asylum for the mentally ill; a madhouse, “lunatic asylum” (OED n. 3a). with him then,
Is this a place for fools or madmen, who
Admitted him? take him, see you
He be well whipt, and let him thanke our mercy,

Bandogbandog A dog tied or chained up, either to guard a house, or on account of its ferocity (OED n. a). Note that to “speak bandog and Bedlam” is a phrase meaning to speak furiously and madly, so it can be gleaned that these lines spoken by the Cousin are an extended play on words..

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I quake already, excellent WarbeckIn this line, Playfair is likening the Cousin’s acting as King to that of Perkin Warbeck, a pretender to the throne who was famous at the time. Warbeck was the titular character in a Caroline-era play by John Ford, which adds another layer of theatricality to this reference. In the 1661 quarto version of The Constant Maid, references to Warbeck are replaced by references to Lambert Simnel, a more recent pretender to the throne (Reimer pp. 146). ,
Coole, coole thy lungs, and whisper with some Lord,
Thou wo't be a key too high else, good Sir Clement,
Master of the house, at whose cost we are entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: In my head, doubt not.

div.stage: Enter Servant 4 disguised as PursevantpursevantOriginally: a junior heraldic officer attendant on a herald or nobleman. In later use: an officer of the English, Scottish, or (formerly) Irish heraldic authority, ranking below a herald; (in Scotland also) a private officer of arms, appointed by an earl (OED “pursuivant” n. 1a)..

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: He waits in the first chamber.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Let the Lutes
Begin, and their best voice, and then admit him.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Here's revelling, my purse must be squeez'd for't:
That's the King, the rest are bare; how supple they are
I'th hams, that Courtier has Oyl'd his joynts,
He looks this way, they point at me; a rot
O'that knave’s finger.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: What fellow's this? who waits?

sp.speaker: Pursevant
sp.l: It was his graces pleasure, he was sent for,
My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Mr. Hornet?
Let me have the honour to present him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Is this the man whom all so much commend
For his ability.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I smell no good from that word, ability.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Discreet and read i'th' Common-wealth, a man
Fit for employment in the State.

sp.speaker: Lord 2
sp.l: The very same.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His countenance is promising.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: If the King of Spaine Philip IV (1605-1665), King of Spain from 1621 to 1665, chose Count-Duke of Olivares (1587-1645) as his royal favourite. After the Twelve Years’ Truce (1609-1621), Olivares’ foreign policy focused on trying to win the Eighty Years’ War, which ended in 1648 with the recognition of the independence of the seven United Provinces (part of the Low Countries), now known as the Netherlands. What Clement implies by this comment is that if Philip IV had not had the Count-Duke of Olivares, his political brain and arm, England would have tried to take over the Netherlands.
Had but his head, that politick head,
I know who might go fish for the Low-Countreyes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: His garments are but course.

sp.speaker: Sir Clement
sp.l: His minde is rich.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: They praise me, I am a thousand pound the worse for’t.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: Wilt please your Majesty?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Kneel downe; Thy name?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Giles Hornet, your poore creature.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Rise up, Sir Giles Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: But am I Knighted?

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: We congratulate your honour.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What must I pay for it?
I'll sell it any friend of yours againe,
For halfe the money.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Some have care to give
His body more becomming ornaments;
He shall be like himselfe, and then we will confer
More honors on him.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do you make haste, his Grace
Will have you new thatch'd; you must have clothes
Fitting your State and honorable title.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: These will be good enough for me, 'las I am not able.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Nay, you must have 'em from his Wardrobe, sir,
They'll cost you nothing; You'll not looke in those,
Like a poore Knight of Windsor.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: When he is ready, give us knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Yes, sir.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Hornet and Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You were best prepare,
Your cloathes will be here presently, the King
Will send for you before you be ready; Cast
Your old skin off: Do you not to save sheets
And trouble, wrap your selves a nights i'th blankets?
Or are they ashamed to show the Linings?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hum? if this be but preparative to a whipping,
What case am I in?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Well said, now they are come;
Be nimble now, and helpe to fit Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Alas, must I weare this doublet? it would yield
Heaven knowes how much to burne.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: You may be desparate
When 'tis on, and burne your body with it, sir,

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I sha'not know my selfe.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Be that time we ha' done wi'ye.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Fit as they were made, sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Which is Sir Giles?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I am the man you please to call Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Then I congratulate your happy fortune;
Y'are like to be exalted, his Grace talkes
Much on you, I'll be proud to be your servant:
My Lord, a word.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The Bridegroom, Sir, in great favour, I can tell you,
And new created by his Highnesse, Baron
Of Landskip; his living is far off.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: My very good Lord, my breeches are almost on.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: There be the Keyes.
sp.stage: Takes the keys from Hornet’s pocket, and gives them aside to Lord 1.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: His Grace has pleas'd to shine upon
A piece of barren earth.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You are too modest;
The King has been informed, Sir Giles, you are
One of the ablest men in his Dominion:
Should vertue still be cloath'd in rags? Advance it
To honour, and regard you waste your braine
At home, in cheap and low engagements, sweat
Your soule out, for a poore and paltry living;
Old houses, let 'em fall to the dull Lord
O'th' Manner; switch me up a Towne together,
Or meddle not; This or that sttragling Acre's
Not worth your care; Study some Monopoly,
May sweep the Kingdome at a stake; Despise
A project wo'not bring in halfe the City;
Finde out a way to forfeit all the Charters;
Have an Exchequer of your owne, and keep
The Princes round about in pension:
These are becomming businesses, and speake
An active State-man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You do talk strange things,
My Lord.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: His keyes are things verie
Materiall to our businesse.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: And I have 'em.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: So, so:
I will account it one of my felicities,
To be a witnesse of your Honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, my good Lord of Landskip.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: How shall we dispose these?

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Hang-man will not have them, and I feare,
They will corrupt a well; 'faith give them stable roome.

sp.speaker: Lord 3
sp.l: My Lord, the King asks for you; Good Sir Giles
Write me i'th' number of your faithfull friends.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We must attend.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Do not yet say he's ready,
The Barber has a dutie to dispatch,
He will be houres a rubbing, washing, powdering.
Then I'll attend him to his Presence.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: We shall excuse him so long, still your servant.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: The Barber, sir, attends in the next roome.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I wo'not shave.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: He feares his throat.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: I never give above three-pence.

sp.speaker: Lord 1
sp.l: Talk not you of charge,
You have but yet your welcome: do not you
Think, good sir Giles, but we can shave you too.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Street near Mistresse Bellamy's House
Enter Close and Startup in his shirt.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where is he, Close?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I told him, sir,
You lay in a chamber o'th t'other side,
The house, whither he is gone with his sword drawne,
And curses of themselves able to kill you:
You did affront him once, and now his Mistresse
Has quite neglected him, for your love, he thinks:
He'll make you an example to all Rivals;
I'll bring your clothes hereafter, yet your feare
And running, sir, will keep you warme enough.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Honest Close, thou hast sav'd my life.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Death, is he not behind you? this way, good sir.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy's House.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Ha’ you not made a fine choyce, I did ever
Think he was false; your mother did but counterfeit
The love-sick widdow all this while, to trie him.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Trie him, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: She told me so her selfe,
Assuring him the state was hers, and you
At her devotion; put him to his choyce,
To take her with the wealth, or you with nothing:
What followed, you have heard, come be wise yet,
And love the Countrey Gentleman that dotes on you;
He's rich, and halfe a foole, I'll fetch him to you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: My mother counterfeit? why may not Hartwell
Pretend as well as she, fearing her anger
And policie, if he refus'd her love?
I have observ'd some sorrow in his gestures,
As he were willing to deliver something,
If opportunitie would give him leave;
He cannot be so false, now I suspect
He does obey some dire necessitie:
'Twould puzzle a wise lover to be so
Severely put to't.

div.stage: Nurse brings in Hartwell in Startups clothes.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: On like a bold Captaine,
Give her a broad sidebroad sideAn attack or onslaught, esp. a fierce verbal attack (OED “broadside” n. 2b)., she's within your shot,
I'll leave you.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis the foole, Why Nurse?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay, fly not before you heare.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: 'Tis Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If my voyce
Betray me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Why in this shape? some trick in't,
He hides his face, I'll put him to't however,
Although the houre be unseasonable, any time
We may expresse our joy: my Nurse once told me
You were not well, and gone to bed, your health
Is welcome as my owne; I dare not, sir,
In modestie presume to bid you stay,
And to requite your paines, kind Mr. Startup.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: She knowes me not.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Forgive me if I blush,
I have no other way, but to declare
My eyes that late frown'd on your love shall smile.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: On me?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: On none but you: I have beene too
Unkindly dealt withall by Hartwell, whom
How dearly I affected, good Heaven knowes:
But I have read discretion to my fancie,
And were he here, he should be witnesse of
My vowes to you, if you accept my heart,
And can with equall truth embrace it, I
Will chuse my husband here; you, only you,
This faith be registred in Heaven, shall challenge from me a wives obedience.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Planet-struckplanet-struckStricken or afflicted, as by paralysis or other sudden physical disorder, as a result of the supposed malign influence of a planet. Hence: seized by sudden fear, amazement, etc.; panic-stricken; bewildered (OED adj.). Note that it is being used as an exclamation in this instance..

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Away, your mother's up; I wo'd not for
A thousand pound she find you in this chamber.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I have undone my selfe.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Sweet Mr. Startup, to your owne lodging,
Take that close lanthorne with you:
Passion of me, what makes her rise?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I will discover yet.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Discover; what?
Ha, Mr. Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You ha' midnight plots.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Oh, we are wretched, miserable, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Oh, who shall lead me to a world where are
No women? Farewell all, I'll be above
Your charms, and find out death, a cure for love.

div.stage: Enter Startup, wrapped in a blanket, followed by Close.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Where are we now? 'tis verie cold, why do'st not
Lead me to some house?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: What, at this time a night?
All people are a bed, the verie Owles
Are in their dead sleep; or if we could
Be admitted, would you venture a this fashion,
And publish your disgrace, proclaime your selfe
Coward, and lay some imputation
Upon the place you came from, where your hopes
May yet be faire for marriage? This brunt over.
To meet some Drunkard now were comfortable,
Whose eyes enflamed might serve for torches,
Or he might spit flapdragons from his fire
Of Sack, and light us: But no sober man,
Considering what case you are in, sir,
By my consent should see you.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Where, where? a fire-drake.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Now 'tis gone: 'tis bright
Agen, Is't not a spirit? Oh deliver me.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I have heard some such things use to walke the fields.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Pray, pray with as much strength
As if you had no land, or were confined
To my annuity: Now I feare no spirits;
This riches makes us cowards; Hide your selfe,
I will go neerer.

sp.speaker: Startup
sp.l: Dost know the devill if thou seest him, Close?
A pox of love, if this be the reward on't;
Some call it fire, but I finde no such matter;
